bestBHT.bht: Jesus referred to the Jews as the lost sheep, emphasizing their state of being lost and abandoned by faithless shepherds. By calling them lost, He expressed pity and compassion rather than blame. The gospel commission was initially directed towards the Jews, who were wandering and lost like sheep without a shepherd. This term highlights both the Jews' need for redemption and salvation and symbolically represents the condition of the entire human race. Jesus wanted His disciples to dedicate their efforts to these lost sheep, recognizing them as chosen by God for redemption and salvation.

Henry Alford: 6. the lost sheep] See besides reff. ch. ix. 36: John x. 16.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Until Christ's death, which broke down the middle wall of partition, the Gospel commission was to the Jews only."
the visible people of God, were 'lost sheep,' not merely in the sense which all sinners are but as abandoned and left to wander from the right way by faithless shepherds."
the Gospel commission was to the Jews only, who, though the visible people of God, were 'lost sheep.'
Albert Barnes: He regarded them as wandering and lost, like sheep straying without a shepherd.
They had been the chosen people of God; they had long looked for the Messiah.
It was proper that the gospel should be first offered to them.
Marvin Vincent: The lost sheep [τα προβατα τα απολωλοτα] . The Greek order throws the emphasis on lost; the sheep, the lost ones. Bengel observes that Jesus says lost oftener than led astray. Compare Matthew 18:12, Matthew 18:14.
John Calvin: He calls them lost sheep, partly that the apostles, moved by compassion, may more readily and with warmer affection run to their assistance.
At the same time, under the figure of this nation, Christ taught what is the condition of the whole human race.

In a word, by the term sheep, Christ recommends the Jews to the apostles, that they may dedicate their labors to them, because they could recognize as the flock of God none but those who had been gathered into the fold.
Philip Schaff: Matthew 10:6. Lost sheep (comp. Matthew 9:36). As most needy and most ready.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus uses it not in blame, but in pity (Bruce).
Bengel notes that Jesus says 'lost' more frequently than 'led astray.'
If the Jewish nation could be brought to repentance the new age would dawn (McNeile).
John Gill: By 'the lost sheep' of this house, are meant either all the people of the Jews in general, who were wandering, and were lost in error and sin, and to whom the external ministry of the Gospel came; or rather the elect of God among them, for whose sake particularly the apostles were sent unto them.
These are called 'sheep', because they were chosen of God, and given to Christ to be redeemed, looked up, sought out, and saved by him.

And 'lost' ones, not only because lost in Adam, and by their own transgressions, so that neither they themselves, nor any mere creature, could save them from eternal ruin and destruction; but also, because they were made to go astray, and were lost through the negligence and errors of their pastors, the Scribes and Pharisees.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse speaks of the lost sheep, emphasizing their state of being lost and abandoned by faithless shepherds. Jesus uses this term not in blame, but in pity, highlighting the compassionate nature of His ministry. He calls the Jews, the visible people of God, the lost ones, in need of redemption and salvation. The Gospel commission at that time was intended for the Jews, who were wandering and lost like sheep without a shepherd. By referring to them as lost sheep, Jesus not only urges His disciples to offer assistance with warm affection but also symbolically teaches about the condition of all humanity as well. The lost sheep of this house represents the Jews who were wandering and lost in error and sin, awaiting the external ministry of the Gospel. Jesus wanted His disciples to dedicate their labors to them, recognizing that they were chosen by God to be redeemed, sought out, and saved.

Jesus referred to the Jews as the lost sheep, emphasizing their state of being lost and abandoned by faithless shepherds. By calling them lost, He expressed pity and compassion rather than blame. The gospel commission was initially directed towards the Jews, who were wandering and lost like sheep without a shepherd. This term highlights both the Jews' need for redemption and salvation and symbolically represents the condition of the entire human race. Jesus wanted His disciples to dedicate their efforts to these lost sheep, recognizing them as chosen by God for redemption and salvation.

Jesus referred to the Jews as the lost sheep, highlighting their lost and abandoned state due to faithless shepherds. He expressed pity and compassion for them. The gospel commission was primarily for the Jews, who were wandering and lost like sheep without a shepherd. This term represents the condition of all humanity. Jesus wanted His disciples to dedicate their efforts to these lost sheep, recognizing them as chosen by God for redemption and salvation.
